wikipedia_page.main: John Bacon Sawrey Morritt (1772? – 1843) was an English traveller, politician and classical scholar.

response: In 1803 Rose met Walter Scott in London. They became friends, and it was through Rose that Scott came to know John Bacon Sawrey Morritt. Scott addressed to Rose the introductory poem of Marmion in 1808, from his house Ashestiel, Ettrick Forest.

Robinson was forced in 1769 to dispose of Rokeby Park, which had been in the possession of his family since 1610, to John Sawrey Morritt, the father of John Bacon Sawrey Morritt. Anna Eliza Bray wrote of his fondness for "books, the fine arts, music, and refined society", and mentions the weakness of his eyes. At last he became blind, and her father used to read to him.
